text: ...General Ike. I hear the sound of many wings ahead. It would seem Kilvas soldiers have joined the troops of Daein for this fight.

speaker: Ike
text: Is Kilvas's contingent larger than the what we faced in the last battle?

speaker: Ulki
text: There are many... But what causes me more concern is the voice of King Kilvas.

speaker: Ike
text: The king himself is cooperating with Daein?

speaker: Ulki
text: Yes. And compared to the other crows, the king is in a class by himself. We must be cautious.

speaker: Ike
text: An entire unit under the command of King Kilvas? I think that bodes ill for us.

speaker: Soren
text: The outcome of the battle hinges on how we deal with them.

speaker: Titania
text: Kilvas soldiers, hm? As fellow bird tribe laguz, what can you tell us about them?

speaker: Janaff
text: Please don't lump us together with those carrion birds.

speaker: Ulki
text: We're not partial...to the crows.

speaker: Ike
text: As you know, we are outmanned by the Daein troops. Is there any way to get the ravens to withdraw? That would be a tremendous help.

speaker: Janaff
text: ...Well, suppose I could go meet with King Kilvas... If I had to. I don't think that my speaking to him is going to make a difference, though.

speaker: Ulki
text: If you like, we will try, but...Don't expect anything to come of it.

speaker: Reyson
text: No matter the circumstance, I will never again speak to a crow.

speaker: Soren
text: No matter what we decide, sitting here like this is giving the enemy more time to prepare.

speaker: Ike
text: You're right. Come on, let's get moving!

speaker: Daein Soldier
text: Sir! The Crimean army has arrived!

speaker: Homasa
text: I hope they are prepared to pass into oblivion. For this will be their final resting place!

speaker: Naesala
text: Crimean stragglers joined with an army on loan from Begnion. I've even heard they have a betrayer in their midst. And yet they still march on... What an odd group. But as long as Kilvas stands at the side of Daein, they have no future. Ah, I suppose they're just unlucky.

speaker: Nasir
text: It appears the enemy has spotted us.

speaker: Ike
text: Well, a group this large is hard to miss.

speaker: Nasir
text: How will you proceed?

speaker: Ike
text: No tricks. Nothing fancy. We'll hit them from the front--fast and hard.

speaker: Nasir
text: I'm sure you're already aware of this, but if you don't do something about Kilvas, you're at a disadvantage.

speaker: Ike
text: Yes, I've heard about the ravens... But even so, it's not as if we can turn tail and run away.

speaker: Nasir
text: Now that I think on it, King Kilvas and Prince Reyson used to be close friends. Did you ask him to speak to the king?

speaker: Ike
text: He was most emphatic in his refusal. It seems that Naesala was responsible for Reyson's capture at the hands of Duke Tanas. I can't really blame him.

speaker: Nasir
text: And the hawks? They, too, are of the bird tribes. Surely some connection can be found there.

speaker: Ike
text: They...weren't very excited about the suggestion.

speaker: Nasir
text: You could command them to do it.

speaker: Ike
text: There's an antagonism between the tribes that we don't understand. I'd rather not force the issue. Trying to coerce them into it would be...unfair. I will let them do as they please.

speaker: Nasir
text: That is so very like you. However, giving orders that are unpopular is often necessary when one is in command, and--

speaker: Ike
text: Maybe so. But I can only do things the best I know how. My own way.

speaker: Ike
text: Come, it's time to go!

speaker: Naesala
text: You...

speaker: Janaff
text: King Kilvas! You egg-stealing snake.

speaker: Naesala
text: One of Tibarn's flock, eh? You are his eyes, if I'm not mistaken.

speaker: Janaff
text: It's not enough that you sold the White Prince to humans? Now you're fighting against laguz?

speaker: Naesala
text: You hawks rescued Reyson didn't you? So everything worked out in the end! What's the problem?

speaker: Janaff
text: I'd like you to repeat those words to the prince's face.

speaker: Naesala
text: Reyson is here? HERE?! Why?!

speaker: Janaff
text: He supports the Crimean army! The beorc leading this army helped him to escape Serenes Forest.

speaker: Naesala
text: Helped him? Are you saying a human came to the aid of Reyson? A laguz?

speaker: Janaff
text: Yes! And he rescued Princess Leanne, too!

speaker: Naesala
text: Leanne...is alive?

speaker: Janaff
text: Don't play the fool! You know the life of the forest has returned. That was their power at work.

speaker: Naesala
text: I see. That's how the forest...Of course.

speaker: Janaff
text: Listen up, crow! You need to fly over there and talk to the prince. If you don't do it, I'm gonna know that you really are the enemy and report that back to King Tibarn. Think it over!

speaker: Naesala
text: Yes... Mmm...What to do.

speaker: Naesala
text: You...

speaker: Ulki
text: King Kilvas. Why have you decided to make the laguz your enemy?

speaker: Naesala
text: One of Tibarn's flock, eh? You are his ears, if I'm not mistaken.

speaker: Ulki
text: Why did you sell Prince Reyson to a beorc?

speaker: Naesala
text: You hawks rescued Reyson didn't you? So everything worked out in the end! What's the problem?

speaker: Ulki
text: Would you repeat your words to Prince Reyson himself?

speaker: Naesala
text: Reyson is here? HERE?! Why?!

speaker: Ulki
text: The beorc leading this army helped him to escape Serenes Forest.

speaker: Naesala
text: Helped him? Are you saying a human came to the aid of Reyson? A laguz?

speaker: Ulki
text: That is what I say. He also rescued Princess Leanne.

speaker: Naesala
text: Leanne...is alive?

speaker: Ulki
text: She was asleep for all these years. The forest protected her. Their voices brought the forest back to life.

speaker: Naesala
text: Of course, so that's how...

speaker: Ulki
text: Why don't you try speaking to Prince Reyson? If you do that, perhaps King Tibarn's rage will burn less brightly.

speaker: Naesala
text: Tibarn's rage, eh? Hmm...Mmm...

speaker: Naesala
text: Reyson!

speaker: Naesala
text: Hey, Reyson! Look at you! You look sharp, kid!

speaker: Reyson
text: Go...away...

speaker: Naesala
text: Oh, so you can talk.

speaker: Reyson
text: You... How dare you show your face to me!

speaker: Naesala
text: Well, I have been called brazen before. Some have gone so far as to say shameless. Come on, at least let me give you a reason.

speaker: Reyson
text: Begone! My ears are closed to you.

speaker: Naesala
text: Reyson, we're friends, are we not?

speaker: Reyson
text: Oh, yes! Friends! In fact, we're such good friends that you sold me to that foul, bloated man!

speaker: Naesala
text: I didn't really sell you! Besides, I planned on rescuing you right away. You were just impatient and flew away on your own, so--

speaker: Reyson
text: Are you blaming me?

speaker: Naesala
text: No, no! Well, maybe... I mean...It was I who was in the wrong. On all accounts.

speaker: Naesala
text: No one was hurt in the end. Come on, smooth those ruffled feathers. All right?

speaker: Reyson
text: Leanne is alive.

speaker: Naesala
text: Yes, Tibarn's attendant told me. That's wonderful news. When he sees her face, I'm sure King Lorazieh will begin to feel better at once. Things are really looking up, aren't they, Reyson?

speaker: Reyson
text: ...I suppose that... If you hadn't deceived me and taken me to the forest... We might not have discovered her... So, I will forgive you. Just this once!

speaker: Naesala
text: Reyson! Oh, that's--

speaker: Reyson
text: WITH...conditions. Will you accept them?

speaker: Naesala
text: ...What are they?

speaker: Reyson
text: Pull your troops from this battle. Now. And never again enter into combat against your fellow laguz.

speaker: Naesala
text: Oh, come now, Reyson. That's asking too much--

speaker: Reyson
text: What will you do, then? Will you continue to fight the Crimean army to which I'm in service?

speaker: Naesala
text: Very well. You win, Reyson. I'll leave and take my soldiers with me. However, I cannot say what the future will bring. I have the fate of my nation to consider after all.

speaker: Reyson
text: Hmm... Very well.

speaker: Naesala
text: So, we're friends again? Come to Kilvas for a visit, will you? Nealuchi will be so pleased.

speaker: Reyson
text: I'll do that. When this war is over, Leanne and I will both come.

speaker: Naesala
text: Oh, and as for Tibarn...

speaker: Reyson
text: I'll speak with him. There's no need for you to worry.

speaker: Naesala
text: Thank you. Farewell. And watch yourself! This is war, you know?

speaker: Naesala
text: Oh, I almost forgot. I've got something for you. Call it an I'm sorry present.

speaker: Reyson
text: Eh? What's this supposed to be?

speaker: Naesala
text: It's a human trinket. It's called a knight ring.

speaker: Reyson
text: Something made by beorc?

speaker: Naesala
text: Don't make such a disgusted face. I tried it, and it proved to be quite useful.

speaker: Reyson
text: Understood. I'll take it for now.

speaker: Naesala
text: Don't get killed, Reyson. If anything were to happen to you... Nealuchi would never let me hear the end of it.

speaker: Reyson
text: Naesala... Thank you.

speaker: Naesala
text: Listen to me, darkwings! We of Kilvas are leaving. Turn at once and head for home.

speaker: Homasa
text: Kilvas has betrayed us?

speaker: Daein Soldier
text: I think abandoned would be more accurate, but--

speaker: Homasa
text: Idiot! It's the same thing! Aaaargh! Accursed sub-humans! We should never have trusted them.

speaker: Homasa
text: My sword is lightning! Do you think you can follow its dance?

speaker: Homasa
text: ...The shame...

speaker: Naesala
text: Oh ho! Black wings! Among humans these are considered bad omens, are they not? Then take these omens as fact, and let them herald you to the afterlife!

speaker: Naesala
text: N-no... This cannot be...Is this...my...fate? What of Kilvas--

speaker: Naesala
text: Guaa... I was careless...and you're better than expected. To me, my brethren! We leave at once!

speaker: Raven Laguz
text: King Naesala, the Daein army has been routed!

speaker: Naesala
text: How nice. What a lot of braggarts they turned out to be. Very well, let us withdraw as well.

speaker: Raven Laguz
text: Are you sure? If we retreat now, what will General Petrine say?

speaker: Naesala
text: Promises made to humans are worth less than a dead snake. Forget about her. Losing the remainder of our payment stings, but still... You can't buy your life back, can you?

speaker: Raven Laguz
text: Good point. Well made, sir.

speaker: Naesala
text: Fly, my darkwings! We return to Kilvas!

speaker: Ike
text: We won...somehow.

speaker: Nasir
text: It's because you did an excellent job of driving off the ravens.

speaker: Ike
text: Yeah, if we had continued to fight them, we would have suffered more casualties than this. I must extend thanks to Reyson.

speaker: Elincia
text: My lord Ike! I'm pleased to see you well. You haven't been injured, have you?

speaker: Ike
text: Princess Elincia. I'm fine. I'm unharmed.

speaker: Elincia
text: Oh, that's good...

speaker: Titania
text: Ike! May I have a word? And if you don't mind, Princess Elincia, would you join us as well? Please join me in that building.

speaker: Elincia
text: What could it be?

speaker: Ike
text: Let's go see.

speaker: Elincia
text: This is...

speaker: Ike
text: Holy...

speaker: Titania
text: Incredible, no? It's gold. All of it.

speaker: Ike
text: Daein must be filthy rich! There's so much, it doesn't even seem real. What do we do with it?

speaker: Soren
text: It's the spoils of war. So naturally, it's ours.

speaker: Ike
text: In that case, I'd like to borrow fifty thousand. Would that be all right?

speaker: Titania
text: That's a lot of money. What are you planning on doing?

speaker: Ike
text: It's a private matter...

speaker: Titania
text: I apologize, Commander. You're not a child. There's no reason for me to pry.

speaker: Ike
text: No, if I may borrow the fifty thousand, that will be more than--

speaker: Titania
text: You won't borrow it, you'll accept it! And in good faith. The remainder we'll give to Soren for company maintenance. Would that be all right, Princess Elincia?

speaker: Elincia
text: Yes, of course.

speaker: Petrine
text: Grrr...

speaker: Daein Soldier
text: Um, General P-Petrine? P-please, General! I'm just a...m-messenger! H-however...I have to tell you--

speaker: Petrine
text: I already heard, you dunderhead! I hated those filthy crows right from the start. Even so, to be betrayed in such a fashion... Grrr... Someone will pay for this! Oh, you certainly had your way with us, didn't you, King Kilvas? But if you want to make an enemy of Daein, then so be it! Once Gallia's fallen, we'll turn our attention to your puny nation and wipe it off the face of the world!

speaker: Petrine
text: Why are you still there? Do you find me amusing?! Shall I make my lance dance for you?

speaker: Daein Soldier
text: N-no, ma'am! No! Never! N-not at all! I beg your pardon! So sorry... I'll be...going...now...

speaker: Petrine
text: Dog's breath! I need...something. A brilliant plan... If this continues much longer, the king will have my head.

speaker: Volke
text: You wanted to see me?

speaker: Ike
text: You've waited a long time. Take this. It's the gold you were promised.

speaker: Volke
text: Finally scraped it together, eh? I'll gladly accept it.

speaker: Ike
text: Aren't you going to count it?

speaker: Volke
text: There's no need. I'll trust you.

speaker: Ike
text: All right, then I'll take what was promised. The report you wrote for my father.

speaker: Volke
text: There isn't one.

speaker: Ike
text: What?

speaker: Volke
text: There is no report. Never was.

speaker: Ike
text: You lied to me? You exploited my need to know more about my father!?

speaker: Volke
text: There is something I must tell you. However, it could not be written down. It is too great of a secret for that. Your father told me to wait until I thought you were mature enough to hear it, and then to tell you myself.

speaker: Ike
text: Mature? Then what was the fifty thousand gold for?!

speaker: Volke
text: Ah, the gold. That was my idea. I thought it would be a good way to test how resourceful and responsible you were.

speaker: Ike
text: Get started. I want to hear it all.

speaker: Volke
text: I've spent a long time as Greil's hired shadow. A long time. I remained hidden from sight in case the day ever arrived that I needed to fulfill my contract... All that time, for one job.

speaker: Ike
text: What was it?

speaker: Volke
text: If Greil were ever to go berserk, I was to stop him. I was to take his life.

speaker: Ike
text: What?!

speaker: Volke
text: Actually, there was one other thing. If Greil were ever slain by his pursuers... I was to watch over his son and tell him Greil's secret at an appropriate time. That was my job.

speaker: Ike
text: Berserk... What are you talking about? Why would you have to kill my father?

speaker: Volke
text: Because of Lehran's Medallion.

speaker: Ike
text: What medallion? What are you talking about?

speaker: Volke
text: The medallion your sister carries.

speaker: Ike
text: Huh? That old bronze thing? I thought it was just a keepsake of my mother's... Are you telling me that it's something more?

speaker: Volke
text: Greil told me it was an object of great peril, but nothing more. I did some investigating on my own, though. And what I discovered...surprised me.

speaker: Ike
text: Tell me.

speaker: Volke
text: Lehran was one of the heron clan, an ancestor of our Prince Reyson, who  carried with him a bronze medallion. Long, long ago, a band of heroes defeated an evil god and imprisoned it therein.

speaker: Ike
text: An evil god? Do you think this is funny? You ARE joking, aren't you?

speaker: Volke
text: Unfortunately, I'm not. And I've no idea how the cursed thing came to be in Greil's possession. That being said, I do know that the men who hunted your father were actually seeking the medallion. Why they wanted it and what they planned to do with it... Just thinking about it gives me chills.

speaker: Ike
text: I'm finding all of this a little hard to believe. You said the medallion was an object of great peril, didn't you? Then why would my father allowMist to carry it around? That doesn't make any sense.

speaker: Volke
text: It's because she can carry it safely. Actually, she's the only one who can. If you want proof, think back. Have you ever once touched it?

speaker: Ike
text: ...No. I haven't. A long time ago, I remember reaching out for it while Mist had it in her hand... My father scolded me harshly. After that, I assumed...it was my sister's alone, and I never reached for it again.

speaker: Volke
text: Compared to other people, the balance within your sister is extremely strong. Your mother, it seems, was the same. That's why they could bear it safely. The medallion is like a strong poison. It takes the worst aspects of a person and magnifies them a thousandfold. Greil touched it only once, and it drove him to complete madness.

speaker: Ike
text: So that's what you meant when you said he went berserk?

speaker: Volke
text: That's right. Beorc and laguz are made up of two forces: balance and chaos. In this, there is no difference between us. It is the proportion of balance to chaos that determines how much the medallion affects a person. In that sense, it predicts how much harm that person might do.

speaker: Volke
text: Your father was one of the preeminent swordsmen of his generation. That day, after he touched the medallion...Twenty soldiers had come for him. Twenty highly trained killers. Your father barely broke a sweat cutting them down. Then he began attacking his neighbors, those who had taken him in, concealed his identity, and called him friend. He slew them one by one, until your mother rushed in...thinking only to save her husband from himself.

speaker: Volke
text: It was over in an instant. Your mother grabbed the medallion from his hand and stepped away from him...They say she smiled as he pulled his sword from her breast and forgave him as her life's blood spilled into the street.

speaker: Ike
text: My father...killed my mother? No. That can't be...

speaker: Volke
text: It was the medallion. Its power is too great for any man. Even one of your father's caliber. Me? You? If either of us touched it, I'm certain that we both would have been consumed by madness. When your father regained his senses, he tracked me down. It seems he'd heard rumors of me some time before. He said he had need of someone like me: closemouthed, skilled, and most importantly, willing to do any sort of work. Of course, after hearing what he wanted me to do, I turned him down. Greil was once a famed general... He was Sir Gawain, one of Daein's Four Riders, and I recognized him at once. There was no chance someone like me would ever be able to stop him.

speaker: Ike
text: But you took the job anyway...Why did you change your mind?

speaker: Volke
text: Greil had lost his wife, and his grief was overpowering. To keep anything like that from happening again, he crippled himself. He slashed the tendons in his sword hand so that he could not wield a sword again. I took the job only because he had become someone my skill could handle. And even then, he was still far stronger than most men...

speaker: Ike
text: I... I don't know what to say...

speaker: Volke
text: That is Greil's secret, as I know it. I now entrust to you the responsibility of seeing that the medallion does not fall into the wrong hands. Your sister must keep it.

speaker: Ike
text: ...As my father lay dying, he told me to forget everything and live in peace. What did he mean?

speaker: Volke
text: He didn't want you to lose yourself and go hunting for revenge, I suppose. He was killed much, much sooner than he ever expected to be.

speaker: Ike
text: So my father's dying wish was for me to protect the medallion? If I can do that, everything will be all right?

speaker: Volke
text: I believe so. At the very least, that must take precedent over everything else.

speaker: Ike
text: I understand.

speaker: Volke
text: Well then, my work here is done.

speaker: Volke
text: Whatever you decide to do now is up to you.

speaker: Ike
text: If I call, can I count on your assistance again?

speaker: Volke
text: If I'm not busy with anything else, I might agree to work for you again. Farewell.

speaker: Ike
text: Father...

speaker: Volke
text: Oh, one last thing.

speaker: Ike
text: What is it?

speaker: Volke
text: Do you want to hire me? In the event that you go berserk someday? If we make a deal now, you won't have to worry about it anymore. As for payment... I can take it out of the fifty thousand you just gave me. What do you say?

speaker: Ike
text: Please.

speaker: Volke
text: That's a wise decision....And in that case, I no longer need to conceal my true identity.

speaker: Ike
text: Huh?

speaker: Volke
text: I'm not really a thief. I'm an assassin. From now on, I'll take on any job you've got, no matter how...dirty.

speaker: Ike
text: Father... Mother......Oh, why...

speaker: Mist
text: Bye. See ya later!

speaker: Jill
text: Yep. Oh, Mist! Watch your step! It's slippery...

speaker: Mist
text: Whooooa!

speaker: Jill
text: Mist!

speaker: Mist
text: Ow! I landed right on my butt! Hee hee! This snow's cold!

speaker: Jill
text: Be careful!

speaker: Mist
text: All righty! Hey, watch, Jill! I'm gonna make a snow angel! Wheeee!

speaker: Jill
text: ...It must be nice to be so cheerful.

speaker: Unknown
text: Jill!

speaker: Jill
text: ...Who's there?

speaker: Haar
text: It's me.

speaker: Jill
text: Captain Haar? B-but...This is an enemy camp!

speaker: Haar
text: I've been trying to track you down ever since you disappeared at Toha. I figured you were off chasing after the Crimeans. I never imagined that you would join up with them.

speaker: Jill
text: At first, it was just circumstance, but... But now it's different. Now I'm with them because I want to be. Spending time with them--and coming into contact with laguz--has shown me what a fool I've been.

speaker: Haar
text: Laguz? I never thought I would hear that word from someone who once said sub-human with such absolute hatred. Sounds like you've had some good experiences with this happy little band.

speaker: Jill
text: I knew that if anyone would understand, it would be you, Captain.

speaker: Haar
text: So you're forming your own set of values for the first time. That's good. That's very, very good. But what are you planning to do now? If you keep moving forward, you're going to face General Shiharam before long.

speaker: Jill
text: Causing trouble for my father was never my intent. However...As a member of this army, I will face him with my shoulders straight and my head held high.

speaker: Haar
text: So you're determined to see this through?

speaker: Jill
text: I am!

speaker: Haar
text: So be it. Then there's nothing left to be said. Farewell. The next time we meet, it will be as enemies. Prepare yourself... And get some rest! You know how important it is.

speaker: Mist
text: Ike? Can I talk to you? A few minutes ago, a man I've never seen before showed up and spoke to Jill. I wasn't sure what was going on, so I went and found you. W-what should we do? Whatever they're talking about, it sure looks serious!

speaker: Ike
text: Jill trained in the Daein army. Fighting against her countrymen will be tough...No matter how prepared she thinks she is.

speaker: Mist
text: I don't care what happens! You can't let her fight against her own father! All right, Ike?

speaker: Ike
text: Hmmm. It might not be a bad idea to keep her at the base camp...Just while we're in Daein.

speaker: Boyd
text: What do you think, guys? Are we going to be able to perform a new special attack?

speaker: Oscar
text: I think we might. I was looking through some old scrolls on fighting techniques, and I found one that looks perfect.

speaker: Boyd
text: Awesome! Nice work!

speaker: Rolf
text: What is it?! What is it!? Come on, tell us how it works!

speaker: Oscar
text: Well, if we want to learn it, there are some things we'll have to do.

speaker: Boyd
text: Aw, dang! I hope it's not all technical, 'cause I won't be able to keep up. Just summarize it, will you?

speaker: Oscar
text: I can do that. All right, the most important thing is we all have to use the same weapon. So, if all three of us can use a bow, that'll be one problem out of the way.

speaker: Boyd
text: A bow? You and I have to use bows?

speaker: Oscar
text: Boyd, are you even listening to me? Yes, we all have to use the same weapon. That's part of the deal.

speaker: Boyd
text: Crud! Nothing we can do about it, I guess. You better not slow us down, Rolf! You little brat.

speaker: Rolf
text: Stop calling me a brat! I'm a better archer than you! If anyone slows us down, it'll be you, Boyd!

speaker: Boyd
text: What did you say? I'm gonna--

speaker: Oscar
text: Knock it off, Boyd! Your skills with a bow aren't as polished as Rolf's. Anyone can see that. Which means that even if Rolf has some natural skill, whoever taught him the fundamentals was an expert archer...

speaker: Boyd
text: Yeah, I know, but he just keeps blabbering this nonsense about how he taught himself.

speaker: Rolf
text: I... I did teach myself! I'm a prodigy.

speaker: Oscar
text: Well, judging by your stance and the way you hold the bow, I think we all know the real story.

speaker: Rolf
text: Eeep!

speaker: Boyd
text: Huh? What is it? What real story?!

speaker: Rolf
text: Oscar! No! Shhh!

speaker: Oscar
text: ...The story... That Rolf's lucky to have a genius like me for a brother, that's what.

speaker: Boyd
text: Aw, stop messing around. This is getting stupid.

speaker: Rolf
text: Whew...

speaker: Unknown
text: What're you guys talking about?

speaker: Ike
text: The three of you have been huddled up here for a while now. What are you scheming?

speaker: Boyd
text: Shh! Um... Uh... Hi, Ike!

speaker: Oscar
text: Scheming is such an ugly word! We're just--

speaker: Rolf
text: Oh, hey, Ike! We're working on this special man--

speaker: Boyd
text: Yaaaaaaaaa!

speaker: Boyd
text: Gaaa...I forgot something...

speaker: Boyd
text: Oooo...gotta go...

speaker: Boyd
text: Sorry about that, Ike. He's been acting a bit odd these days.

speaker: Ike
text: Really? Seems to me that you're the odd one in the bunch.

speaker: Boyd
text: Um, sure, all right! Do us a favor, though, and make sure the three of us are all in the next battle.

speaker: Ike
text: Sure, I guess that's fine. But why?

speaker: Boyd
text: Well, it's a surprise. That's all. We'll show you later! I'm sure you'll like it! Come on! We can't be standing around all day. Let's go! Oscar! Rolf!

speaker: Ike
text: Special man? Hmm... Man......Mandolin?...Manicotti?...Manifesto? Oh, who cares?

speaker: Janaff
text: Brrr... I'll take on any number of enemies, but this snow is another story! I think my beautiful wings are icing over.

speaker: Ike
text: That sounds like trouble. Are you going to be able to fly?

speaker: Janaff
text: ...Yes, of course I can fly. These wings aren't for looks, you know? They're made of flesh and blood and feathers. It's not like I'm some animal that has to hibernate when winter rolls in. Sheesh! Can't you beorc tell the difference between comic exaggeration and serious conversation?

speaker: Ike
text: Um... Oh, I was supposed to laugh, was I? Sorry about that.

speaker: Janaff
text: Oh, my...such sincerity. This is unexpected. It looks like someone taught you manners.

speaker: Ike
text: Er...

speaker: Janaff
text: By the way, I've been meaning to ask...What are our chances for victory?

speaker: Ike
text: We're still at an extreme disadvantage.

speaker: Janaff
text: What? That's not the answer I wanted! You gotta do better than that, beorc general! I'm here! If we lose, how am I ever going to show my face in Phoenicis again?

speaker: Ike
text: We're at a disadvantage, but I don't intend to lose. There's a man in Daein that I need to find...and I will be the last thing that he sees.

speaker: Janaff
text: Ha ha! Well said! I wish you could repeat that to today's younger generation. There are some weaklings back home that I don't even want to call hawks. I'd love to stick 'em back in their eggs and start over from scratch.

speaker: Ike
text: Hey, you hatch from eggs?! Eh?

speaker: Janaff
text: I was speaking figuratively. You know? Like...a metaphor? We haven't hatched from eggs for many generations now. Silly beorc... All right, I'm outta here. I gotta warm up the ol' wings before battle, or who knows what might happen.

speaker: Ike
text: I figured that egg thing was a joke, but I had no idea it ever really happened...Bird tribes... Go figure.

speaker: Ike
text: Excuse me, do you have a moment?

speaker: Ulki
text: ...Oh. General Ike. What is it?

speaker: Ike
text: It's nothing really...I just thought I'd say hello.

speaker: Ulki
text: That's...considerate.

speaker: Ike
text: Um... Your king is very generous, isn't he? And it's not just Reyson I'm talking about. He left us his two retainers as well.

speaker: Ulki
text: ...How do we pertain to the king's generosity?

speaker: Ike
text: I guess it's because Reyson kept apologizing... I just thought that... Am I misinterpreting something?

speaker: Ulki
text: I...don't know. But I know that the king can survive without our help.

speaker: Ike
text: Is that true? That's pretty amazing. I've been given the title of lord, but I still can't run this army on my own. Titania and Soren handle all the little details, and that's what keeps us from collapsing into chaos.

speaker: Ulki
text: Our king...does nothing special. Everyone just does what's needed. There is no chaos.

speaker: Ike
text: He's really trusted, isn't he?

speaker: Ulki
text: That's...natural. In laguz society, the strongest become king. Unlike the beorc, kingship is not tied to blood, so we have no weak kings. I'm sorry... Perhaps that was improper.

speaker: Ike
text: No, I agree with you. Choosing a ruler by strength instead of birth makes much more sense.

speaker: Ulki
text: When we face Begnion troops, we target the units with weak leadership and eliminate them first. Beorc weapons can be very powerful, but not everyone wields them well. Since beorc also choose generals by bloodlines, their competency is uneven...and that is a weakness of beorc armies. As for you, General Ike, the time to prove yourself is approaching.

speaker: Ike
text: It's true. No matter how strong the individuals are, that strength is worthless if they're weak as a unit. An army's power comes from leadership and management... That's good to remember. Thanks.

speaker: Ulki
text: Mmm.
